key_insight: The paper introduces neural stochastic differential equations that learn both state-dependent drift and diffusion to generatively model continuous-time cell dynamics, yielding more accurate and realistic trajectories than prior methods and enabling in silico perturbation studies.
problem_solved: Models for single-cell dynamics often fail to capture continuous-time stochasticity and state-dependent noise, limiting realistic simulation and prediction of developmental or disease perturbations; this work solves that by learning both deterministic and stochastic components from data.
method: Parameterize SDE drift and diffusion as neural networks (neural SDE) to model state-dependent dynamics and noise.
Train the generative model on single-cell time-series/trajectory data to match observed distributions and trajectories.
Use the learned SDE to simulate counterfactuals and perturbations by modifying drift/diffusion or forcing terms for in silico experiments.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a principled, continuous-time generative framework for noisy biological trajectories, improving prediction fidelity and enabling simulated interventions for hypothesis testing and experimental design.
visual_elements: Schematic of neural SDE: neural nets producing state-dependent drift and diffusion feeding into an SDE integrator
Phase-space trajectory plots comparing ground truth, neural SDE simulations, and baseline models
Heatmap or surface of learned state-dependent diffusion over latent/state space
Before/after perturbation simulation panels showing predicted cell-state shifts
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
